newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico seen placing 50 bln yen bond this week.
newsitem.headline: Mexico seen placing 50 bln yen bond this week.

text.p: The Mexican federal government is seen placing a 50 billion yen, seven-year bond issue this week, with an announcement perhaps as soon as today, financial sources said on Wednesday.
Sources said Daiwa Securities could be lead managing the United Mexican States (UMS), or Mexican federal government issue.
It would represent a return to a market that Mexico tapped frequently last year, and continue Mexico's strategy of diversifying the currencies of its debt.
The Mexican government placed three Samurai bonds in 1996.
The first was last March and was a six-year 40 billion yen issue with a yield of 6.0 percent, or 390 basis points over similar U.S. Treasuries.
In June, the UMS issued a 10-year 100 billion yen bond with a yield of 6.75 percent, or 410 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
In September last year, the federal government launched a six-year 70 billion yen issue, worth about $640 million, with a yield of 5.0 percent, or 326 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
